claim: In Germany, France, and Switzerland, you pay with euros.

supporting.text: Germany, France, and Switzerland are all part of the Eurozone, where the euro is the official currency.

attacks.text: Germany, France, and Switzerland are all part of the Eurozone, where the euro is the official currency.
Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone; it uses the Swiss franc as its official currency.
Switzerland has agreements with the EU that allow the euro to be used in certain contexts, even though it is not the official currency.
Some regions in Germany and France, like overseas territories, may use other currencies alongside the euro.
These regions are exceptions and do not represent the general currency usage in Germany and France, where the euro is predominant.

supporting.text: The euro is widely accepted in Germany and France, as they are founding members of the Eurozone.

attacks.text: The euro is widely accepted in Germany and France, as they are founding members of the Eurozone.
Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and primarily uses the Swiss franc, not the euro.
Some businesses in Germany and France may accept other currencies, but the euro is not universally mandatory.
Even though Switzerland is not in the Eurozone, many border regions and tourist areas accept euros for convenience.
The legal tender laws in Germany and France require businesses to accept euros, making it effectively mandatory for most transactions.

supporting.text: Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc as its official currency, not the euro.

attacks.text: Switzerland is not part of the Eurozone and uses the Swiss franc as its official currency, not the euro.
Many businesses in Switzerland accept euros for convenience, especially in border regions.
The Swiss franc is pegged to the euro in some financial mechanisms, making euros functionally relevant.
Accepting euros does not change the fact that the official currency is the Swiss franc, and change is often given in francs.
Pegging mechanisms do not equate to using the euro as legal tender in daily transactions.

supporting.text: While some businesses in Switzerland may accept euros, they are not legally required to do so, and change is often given in Swiss francs.

attacks.text: While some businesses in Switzerland may accept euros, they are not legally required to do so, and change is often given in Swiss francs.
Many businesses in Switzerland, especially in border regions, accept euros as a convenience for tourists and cross-border shoppers.
The Swiss National Bank has policies that facilitate the acceptance of euros in certain sectors, reducing the inconvenience for travelers.
Despite some businesses accepting euros, the official currency of Switzerland is the Swiss franc, and legal transactions must be settled in francs.
Exchange rate fluctuations and additional fees often make using euros in Switzerland less favorable compared to using Swiss francs.
The Swiss National Bank's policies do not override the legal requirement for businesses to settle transactions in Swiss francs.

supporting.text: Germany and France have fully adopted the euro, replacing their former national currencies (Deutsche Mark and French franc).

attacks.text: Germany and France have fully adopted the euro, replacing their former national currencies (Deutsche Mark and French franc).
Switzerland has not adopted the euro and still uses the Swiss franc as its official currency.
Some regions in Germany and France may still accept old currencies in limited transactions, creating inconsistency.
The Swiss franc is widely accepted in border regions of Germany and France, further complicating the claim.
The European Central Bank strictly enforces the use of the euro in Germany and France, minimizing inconsistencies.
